physDesc.p: The letter consists of two pages of typewriter text with a leter head consisting of "Amy Lowell, Heath Street, Brookline Mass." written on the top right corner in pencil is the word "poetry."

div.p: I am enclosing all the poems which you chose, and also the little list of them which you made with your own handwriting, to prove their correctness.

I also send back "The Coal Picker," which I found among my things, just as you said, and "A Tale of Starvation," the latter being, as it were, on perpetual approval, and not, I understand, accepted, and you will take it or not, as you see fit.

I had extremely good luck in New York, you will be glad to know. My "Waltz" was taken by "The International," and the "Century" and "Scribner" both have taken a number to consider, and Mr. Yard of the Century, and Mr. Varick of the International were both so complimentary that my h[sic] head is completely whirled round, and I feel that the only natural way for me to walk would be backward. I do hope that you can put my poems into the
April number, as I am most anxious to have them appear.

I have got two new subscribers for you. At least they promised me that they would subscribe, Miss Carlotta Lowell of New York, and Miss Elizabeth Putnam of Boston, and I wish you could have heard me boom your magazine to all the people I met in New York. Don’t forget that I really mean what I say about reviewing books, and writing any other little articles you may happen to want. I should be perfectly happy to do anything I can. It is all grist to me, and you cannot think how much I have the welfare of your magazine at heart. The more I see of them in New York, editors and their pa[sic] papers, the more I realize that "Poetry" has a field all to itself, and one which I believe to be of immense importance.
